column1: Snicket's Politics and Social Satire - by Antenora
« Thread Started on Jun 30
Mr. Snicket's Politics and Unfortunate Social Satire

We know that Daniel Handler is a liberal, and it appears that his character Snicket shares these views, based on the available evidence-- in his letters to Beatrice, he denounces ""pre-emptive war""(the solution to Olaf's anagram ""a wet viper perm"") as an obscene concept, and expresses sadness over the fact that two women are not allowed to marry. While we know relatively little about the politics of the Snicket world, by our standards Snicket would also be a liberal. He would also strongly disapprove of the ""anti-elitist"" and anti-intellectual leanings commonly shown by some conservatives(but by no means limited to the Right-- consider how Hillary Clinton has dismissed the worth of economic experts). For Snicket, this kind of thinking(or non-thinking) goes hand in hand not only with evil, but with sheer absurdity.
Several of the post-V.F.D. books contain notable social satire
column2: presenting a world not entirely unlike our own:

column1: 1. The obsession with wealth
column2: fashion and conspicuous consumption-- exemplified by the items sold in the aptly named Veblen Hall-- in TEE. Many of these items and fashions
column3: such as keeping whole streets in darkness
column4: climbing dozens of flights of stairs

column1: 2. The tyrannical government of the Village of Fowl Devotees, which resembles a theocracy or a cult with its devotion to crows, censorship of any suggestion of dissent, and medieval-esque method of punishment. Consider also their puritanical ban on ""using one's mouth for recreation"", which implies the sort of restriction of sensual pleasure seen in communities ruled by religion. Even these frightening figures have comical aspects, though, with their silly hats, forbiddance of their own rule books, and nitpicking about ice-cream sundaes.

3. The public's love of humiliation, freakishness, ""violence and sloppy eating"", shown by the visitors to Caligari Carnival. While people like the pimpled man are exaggerated strawman characters, their means of entertainment are not entirely unrealistic-- witness reality shows, torture-themed movies, media coverage of Michael Jackson and Paris Hilton, certain web pages, and rubberneckers at car accidents.

4. The corrupt-yet-absurd High Court in TPP. This is the most powerful political institution we see in ASoUE, and it reflects all the worst aspects of this world's authority and society. Members are either unfathomably evil or too ""laissez-faire"" to hold back evil-- one may draw a parallel to the executive and legislative branches of the current United States government. However, their Scalia-esque interpretation of ""Justice is blind"", like the crow hats, allows us to laugh as well as tremble.

5. Ishmael's government of ""Olaf-Land"", which forms an interesting counterpoint to the Village of Fowl Devotees. Instead of ruling with an iron fist, Ishmael appears gentle(and more sympathetic than the Council of Elders), and his government, while cultish, is more like communism than fascist theocracy. By restricting his subjects' access to knowledge, technology, and most material items, Ishmael attempts to stamp out greed and create a Marxist utopia, which as in our world ultimately turns out to be dystopic. This reflects the ""horseshoe"" theory of the political spectrum, in which the extreme right and the extreme left are more similar than they'd like to admit; it also supports the themes of moral ambiguity which become prominent in these later books, in which there is no clear path to goodness. ""

column1: If you do not mind philosophical, thought-provoking endings that do not tie all the loose ends into pretty little bows, this book IS for you.  ""The End"" is Snicket's most adult book of the series.  All the children I know who've read it loved it, but they did not catch all of the darker tones to the story, as is true of the entire series.  The final book is titled in an ironic sense, as it is not really the end at all but a new beginning, and it is meant to be a more serious reflection of life.  There will NEVER be a neat little book with all the answers in it for you.  It would not be a series of unfortunate events if that were the case.

Now be honest, how do you really feel?""  This really was my favorite book of the whole series because I continued to think about it weeks after I'd read it and still find myself jumping into conversations about it any time it's brought up.

If the lack of resolution to Stuart Little gnawed at you when you were 8 and continues to do so to this very day, I would not recommend picking up this book.  If you enjoy an open ending that is left up to you to decide and mull over, then what are you still reading this for? column1: 1556766675-5081,https://www.amazon.com/End-Unfortunate-Events-Book-13/product-reviews/0064410161/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_hist_5?ie=UTF8&reviewerType=all_reviews&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=1,drebbles,Fitting End to Series,30-Oct-06,"The last book in Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events books finds the Baudelaire orphans washed up on a continental shelf with Count Olaf. For once they seem to have good luck - there is an island nearby and the people living there say the Baudelaire's can live with them, but quickly see what Count Olaf is really like and banish him from the island. But things never run smoothly for the Baudelaires and they soon discover it's difficult to live under the rule of Ishmael who is in charge of the island. Ishmael has some secrets that threaten the welfare of everyone on the island and the Baudelaires find themselves in more danger than they ever have before.

I thought ""The End"" was one of the best books in this thirteen book series. As always, Snicket has a lot of fun with words and names and I laughed at some of the names of the people on the island: Ishmael (call me ""Ish""), Friday, Ariel, Robinson, and Bligh are just a few of the people living there. Sunny no longer uses much baby talk, but Snicket still has fun with her words, sometimes using them backward. As in all the books, the children are, for the most part, smarter and more responsible than the adults around them are.

Readers may be disappointed to find out that while Snicket ties up several loose ends from the previous books, he leaves some major plot lines dangling. Some of it may be sloppy writing, but I suspect much of it was deliberate and I would not be surprised if in the future there was a series of Lemony Snicket books focussing on the Quagmires. While ""The End"" was not as dark as ""The Penultimate Peril"" parents should be aware that there are two deaths in the book.

""The End"" is a fitting ending to a fun, quirky series.",5.0 out of 5 stars,Next page?,https://www.amazon.com/End-Unfortunate-Events-Book-13/product-reviews/0064410161/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_paging_btm_15?ie=UTF8&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=15&reviewerType=all_reviews

I had read interviews with the author in which he said he was often approached at signings by children who had various personal difficulties and identified with the Baudelaires in their search for meaning and for something better, something he had not really anticipated and which he took to heart.  So the message of The End, I think, is really a message to the children who confided in Handler and to others in similar situations--that bad things happen, and sometimes there are no clear answers to why they happen and no way to undo them, but we have to continue to try to overcome our situations anyway and appreciate the good things that do happen.  The allusion to Genesis reminds us that trying to explain why bad things happen is as old as humanity.  If you approach the book in this way, Handler did a remarkable, even heroic, job.

By the way, I believe the poster in The Beatrice Letters shows a scene after the end of the End, which that text describes in a somewhat vague manner.  The whisk in the poster is one way to date the picture.  Apparently the baby has some talent with bats.  Finally, the use of ""brae"" and the multiple meanings of ""bear"" in The End tie into The Beatrice Letters as well. column1: I liked ""The End"" because it was different to the other books - you saw a very strange side of Count Olaf, and although it is the end of the series, it marks a new beginning for the Baudelaire orphans, the Baudelaires grow up, and, they discover an important part of their parents' past.
I think the few questions that were answered in ""The End"" were enough to explain a whole lot of other questions raised in previous books, but not too much to dampen our still-going speculations.

I think the true beauty of ""A Series Of Unfortunate Events"" lies in its mystery, its sadness, its nobility and its ability to waken the curiosity in a person, and all of these things feature wonderfully in the moving ""The End"".

The End"" is a definite must-read for fans of the series, and I recommend you keep in mind the other books when you read it - do not have expectations unlikely to be fulfilled by such a secretive author, but appreciate it for what it is - a touching end to a fantastic series of books.",5.0 out of 5 stars,Next page?,https://www.amazon.com/End-Unfortunate-Events-Book-13/product-reviews/0064410161/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_paging_btm_17?ie=UTF8&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=17&reviewerType=all_reviews

The final book in ""A Series of Unfortunate Events"" contains all the elements, such as humor and wit, that have made the previous twelve books such a success.  But if readers are expecting ""The End"" to bring an end to the misfortune that the Baudelaires face, they should know better than to think it would all be all summed up so tidily.

The reader finds Violet, Klaus and Sunny right where they were at the end of ""The Penultimate Peril"" - adrift at sea with Count Olaf at the helm, still after their fortune and expecting them to be his servants or henchmen.  A violent storm finds them washed up on an isolated island commune that seems to be the ideal safe place - the residents can see through Olaf's veneer and he becomes a outcast.  The Baudelaires are finally safe, or are they?  For things are not all that they appear to be on this island commune, with a leader who is hiding many secrets from his followers that he would rather keep hidden and tries to prevent the orphaned siblings from discovering.  Yet curious as ever, Violet, Klaus and Sunny uncover the dark truth behind the island's community, and its own connection with their parents.  However, while they do uncover some secrets, many more are left unanswered.

The End"" may initially seem like a letdown, especially for readers who were hoping for a tidy summation.  While a bit overly long, it is nevertheless as entertaining as the previous novels in the series.  And while this reader was hoping just a little (like many others) that all the mysteries would be solved, the ambiguous ending leaves room for the story to continue.",5.0 out of 5 stars,Next page?,https://www.amazon.com/End-Unfortunate-Events-Book-13/product-reviews/0064410161/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_paging_btm_16?ie=UTF8&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=16&reviewerType=all_reviews

column1: 1556766684-5119,https://www.amazon.com/End-Unfortunate-Events-Book-13/product-reviews/0064410161/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_hist_5?ie=UTF8&reviewerType=all_reviews&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=1,Orvokki,The best and most thought-provoking book of the series,23-Jan-11,"If you are looking for something to completely satiate your curiosity by answering every single question A Series of Unfortunate Events has raised, you are not doing this book or series justice.  Having read The End, I have come to understand some things that I believe LS is trying to convey.  The world is so full of stories, of evil, of good, and of people who are made up of all three, that to try to know all of it is impossible and not the point.  It is obvious that the Baudelaire orphans have done bad things, but most of us believe that, when all is said, they are really good people.  However, we have read 13 books which have explained that to us.  Count Olaf, on the other hand, we have believed (and maybe many people will still believe) that he is pure wickedness.  In my opinion, the third book complicates that thought immensely.  He says it himself that he, too, has lost important things in his life - ""my parents, my true love, my henchfolk, an enormous amount of money I didn't earn, even the boat with my name on it"" (The End, 312).  And even though we laugh at the ridiculousness of what he says, and for that matter, at the ridiculousness found in all 13 books, it is sad to learn that Olaf is an orphan too and that he has perhaps experienced just as much hardship as the Baudelaires, and as everyone has.

I could describe how much I like the dark and witty humor or the storytelling, but I will just quickly say how much I was moved when I realized what the biq question mark-shaped object was that even Olaf was afraid of in the 12th book - the Great Unknown.  A.k.a. death.  Kit tells the Baudelaire orphans how the Quagmires and the Widdershins were ""either swallowed up or rescued by that mysterious thing"" (The End, 305).  It got me thinking about the theme of death in the series, which has a constant presence.  Most of the time, it's cloaked in descriptions of horrible sadness.  Just how many orphans have been mentioned, anyway?  However, I think the Baudelaire's decision to go deal with the world and leave the island shows that death does not have to control them.  In the end, everyone will die, which is either a blessing or a curse, but in the mean time, the world will always spin and continue to add secret upon secret, and the people who live the stories will continue them.
All in all

I have to conclude that most readers can easily pick out these ""clues"" but some of us are hesitant to jump to the conclusions that others so readily embrace. column1: The End"" not only contains a coherent plot, with a beginning, middle and end (something recent books in the series have lacked), it contains many clever allegories woven into the narrative (including ""taking the apple from the serpent to gain a not-necessarily desirable life""), and several surprisingly adult medidations on philosophical issues.

I can only suppose that reviewers who felt the book lacked merit completely missed these bits of brilliance, and, by doing so, missed Daniel Handler's (aka Lemony Snicket) point in his story of the Baudelaire orphans and their trevails: that the world does not always make sense, that the choice between good and evil is not so clear, and that our choices often have consequences we did not intend, but ones which we must nonetheless live with. But we face this world, ""The End"" tells us, because then and only then can we make it a better place. Depression, denial and running away are not options - they are excuses - which the orphans nevers use, despite every reason to. Kudos to Handler for placing these important truths in a a children's work.

And the book STILL managed to throw in many laugh-out-loud lines (e.g., at one point, when the orphans are skimming a book for vital information, the narrator remarks that when one does skim a book, one tends to get a rather garbled impression of its contents, particularly since some authors like to throw in random sentences to throw off and confuse skimmers. The next sentence in the book, smack-in-the-middle of a life-and-death situation, is ""Three very short men carried off a large door, painted to resemble a large living room"", after which, without missing a beat, the story continues. Genius.).

Don't buy this book expecting answers - that's like buying Kant expecting something like The Da Vinci Code - instead, buy it expecting laughs, ideas, and maybe a few tears, and you won't be disappointed.",5.0 out of 5 stars,Next page?,https://www.amazon.com/End-Unfortunate-Events-Book-13/product-reviews/0064410161/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_paging_btm_21?ie=UTF8&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=21&reviewerType=all_reviews

column1: 1556766675-5074,https://www.amazon.com/End-Unfortunate-Events-Book-13/product-reviews/0064410161/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_hist_5?ie=UTF8&reviewerType=all_reviews&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=1,Josh Mauthe,"A gutsy ending that angered a lot of people, but if you can embrace the mystery, you'll love it",21-Jul-14,"I don't really blame people for being angry at The End. Here's a final volume of a 13-book series that's full of mysteries, conspiracies, unanswered questions, and unknown fates...and it gives us almost no answers at all, instead leaving both us and the characters to live with the questions and try to make their own lives beyond the boundaries of this series. It's a bold move, but it's in keeping with the rest of Lemony Snicket's Series of Unfortunate Events, which has always been less interested in its plot and more interested in turning its simple story into something more profound and complex than you expected. By the end of the final volume, villains get a chance at redemption, heroes fall pitifully, leaders fail their people, and the book becomes more and more fascinatingly symbolic, becoming - in some ways - a meditation on death and the unknowns in each of our lives. That's heady stuff for just about any book, much less a children's book series, but it's part of what made me love the Snicket books so much, and part of what I love as an English teacher about the set - what better way to introduce children to complex concepts and postmodern literature that comments on itself, experiments with its form, and shatters its fourth wall so many times that it becomes non-existent. But as much as I love a lot about The End, I can't deny that the main story of the book - which involves an island community - is an odd one that feels a bit like filler or an afterthought, disconnected from the rest of the series and essentially a bit disconnected even from some of the themes and ideas at work throughout the rest of the book. Still, I love The End - I love how odd it is, and how much Snicket is willing to risk angering people to deliver the ending that the series deserves, one that embraces the mystery at its core rather than unraveling it. And it does it all while still being funny, gleefully odd, wonderfully complicated, and surprisingly emotionally moving. A good ending to a great series, and one whose gutsiness elevates the series as a whole to something more than the sum of its parts.",5.0 out of 5 stars,Next page?,https://www.amazon.com/End-Unfortunate-Events-Book-13/product-reviews/0064410161/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_paging_btm_15?ie=UTF8&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=15&reviewerType=all_reviews

column1: My son's comment this evening, unable to stop after beginning Chapter Twelve, was, ""Oh, Daddy, it is so sad,"" which echoed my feelings exactly. The Baudelaire Orphans have had to grow up so quickly and have given up so much in the process. Doubtless Mr. Snicket would have a good laugh at any idea that his 13 volume joke could be taken seriously, or worse, evoke feelings of empathy for his outrageous characters and situations, but at least for me and my son, that is exactly what happened. We lived the Baudelaire's lives and ultimately reaped the very bittersweet rewards that they did.

'A Series of Unfortunate Events' achieves nothing less than the exact opposite of what its author (perhaps) set out to do. A literary joke that gradually evolves into a minor masterpiece of dark humor and a subtle - and sometimes not-so-subtle - investigation of the human heart.

The setting of this story makes for a rather slow plot progession at times, but it does allow Snicket to show his flair for the English language. The main themes of the book are 1. There are many layers to a story 2. It depends on how you look at things and 3. Sometimes a word can have two meanings (such as cordial the drink, cordial the demeanor). These themes also apply to the entire book Series. The 13 books presented by Snicket only represent the Baudelaires story, and some questions are not answered in this book because it is another layer within the story. You can also figure out, if you read carefully, how Lemony is known to the Baudelaires' mother. Snicket does his duty of reporting the events of the orphans, and leaves it open for himself to report more on the many characters in the many layers of the V.F.D. column1: 1556766677-5088,https://www.amazon.com/End-Unfortunate-Events-Book-13/product-reviews/0064410161/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_hist_5?ie=UTF8&reviewerType=all_reviews&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=1,Dorothy,gorgeous,19-Oct-06,"I'd like to say something in response to many of the reviews here.  I've been reading these books for years now and have always appreciated the duplicity of these books and the puzzle they present for the reader.  It's almost a throwback (probably intentionally) to the double nature of Renaissance literature.  I wouldn't say (because I haven't found enough evidence to prove this) that they are any sort of full-fledged allegory but double-meanings are highly prevalent in these books.  In other words, as another reader above mentioned, a sheep is not just a sheep.  The point is, this isn't just about some kids who get shipwrecked on an island and it's not in any way boring (at least for someone who ""gets"" it).  It's a highly mature exploration of human nature and the basic moral conflicts and problems that every human being faces in some way or another.  Life isn't cut and dry, there is no black and white but only a mass of grey.  Books with sugary sweet happy endings are all well and good but, as far as children's lit goes (and all lit for that matter), the stories that cut to the heart and have the most meaning are those such as these books that leave a certain amount of moral ambiguity and really deal with humanity not some escapist concoction.  That's why I think these make wondrous children's books (not even I would rank Handlers cumbrous prose as high literature), not only do they familiarize kids with literary concepts (deus ex machina, memento mori and the like) and through profuse allusions with many of the world's greatest literary works, they refuse to fool children into thinking that life is easy, boy meets girl and everything eventually works out for the righteous and true at heart.  As we all discover at some point, life doesn't work that way.  All we have, like the Baudelaire children at the end of the end, is each other and our dignity.  From this perhaps we can cobble a life and a world worth living in.

And that's why this book and the entire series have been gorgeous.  I honestly can't wait to share them with my kids.",5.0 out of 5 stars,Next page?,https://www.amazon.com/End-Unfortunate-Events-Book-13/product-reviews/0064410161/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_paging_btm_16?ie=UTF8&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=16&reviewerType=all_reviews

column1: What I Liked: The drastic shift in tone for this book versus all the others was rather jarring at first as any other book would end with some some of big confrontation with the villain who has chased and tormented our heroes for so long. But instead we start with the villain sharing the same boat with them and yet being left out by the odd island community from the very beginning. They don't even get fooled by another of his disguises that had fooled so many others across all the past titles. And this made for a very interesting setting to start the last part of this greater story.

And there are so many lessons brought forward in this book as a culmination of all that had come before. Everything that the Baudelaires had experienced across the series became rather important in this final chapter yet also irrelevant to how the characters would eventually move forward. This is more than just a story of good versus evil. And that's where the genius of this book really lies as it gives a new layer of meaning on top of everything that had come before.
